title: bootstrap script cannot handle custom python install paths
body:
The bootstrap is not able to deal with custom python3 install locations. It requires that `pip` is found with the following folder structure:
```
external/usr/lib/python$pyver/site-packages
```
I am referring to this [line](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/d08a2cb66703efd7e860633ade28244713d43a92/bootstrap.sh#L54). This is fine for system python, but when I use a python3 installed on a different location, I get the following:

```
==> 941182: reframe: Executing phase: 'install'                                    
==> [2020-09-21-09:03:36.432361, 941186] '/usr/bin/bash' './bootstrap.sh' ''       
==> python3 -m ensurepip --root external/ --default-pip                            
Looking in links: /tmp/tmpsiva_b_g                                                 
Requirement already satisfied: setuptools in /my/spack/install/path/opt/spack/linux-centos8-broadwell/gcc-8.3.1/py-setuptools-46.1.3-n2by5yrsutgd3v6gwpbeelenw3eox2z5/lib/python3.7/site-packages (46.1.3)
Collecting pip                                                                     
Installing collected packages: pip                                                 
Successfully installed pip-19.2.3                                                  
==> python3 -m pip install -q --upgrade pip --target=external/                     
/my/spack/install/path/opt/spack/linux-centos8-broadwell/gcc-8.3.1/python-3.7.7-w27qutd7t3uor2sqlpdsfyv4fbfdiole/bin/python3: No module named pip 
==> python3 -m pip install -q -r requirements.txt --target=external/ --upgrade  
/my/spack/install/path/opt/spack/linux-centos8-broadwell/gcc-8.3.1/python-3.7.7-w27qutd7t3uor2sqlpdsfyv4fbfdiole/bin/python3: No module named pip 
==> [2020-09-21-09:03:39.464072, 941186] Installing /tmp/hvictor/spack-stage/spack-stage-reframe-3.1-kxtmks6dzyny5y6mssaikwry6sgxlu5w/spack-src to /my/spack/install/path/opt/spack/linux-centos8-broadwell/gcc-8.3.1/reframe-3.1-kxtmks6dzyny5y6mssaikwry6sgxlu5w
```

The actual place where `pip` got installed was
```
/my/spack/install/path/opt/spack/linux-centos8-broadwell/gcc-8.3.1/reframe-3.1-kxtmks6dzyny5y6mssaikwry6sgxlu5w/external/my/spack/install/path/opt/spack/linux-centos8-broadwell/gcc-8.3.1/python-3.7.7-w27qutd7t3uor2sqlpdsfyv4fbfdiole
```

title: ReFrame may not restore the environment correctly if a module load has failed in previous test
body:
In order to reproduce, you need a modules system and the following test file:

```python
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.simple_test
class Test0(rfm.RunOnlyRegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.executable = 'echo $TESTMOD_FOO'
        self.modules = ['testmod_foo', 'xxx']
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found('FOO', self.stdout)


@rfm.simple_test
class Test1(rfm.RunOnlyRegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.executable = 'echo $TESTMOD_FOO'
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_not_found('FOO', self.stdout)
```

How to reproduce it:

```
module use $(pwd)/unittests/modules
./bin/reframe -C myconfig_with_modules_system.py -c path/to/the/test/above.py -r
```

Then you will notice that the second test will fail, meaning that it finds the variable that was set inside the `testmod_foo` module.

```
[  FAILED  ] Ran 2 test case(s) from 2 check(s) (2 failure(s))
```

If you run `Test1` individually, it passes as expected:

```
[       OK ] (1/1) Test1 on tresa:default using builtin [compile: 0.012s run: 0.403s total: 0.445s]
```

This bug comes from here https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/master/reframe/core/runtime.py#L224. This should be in a `try/finally` block and the environment must always be restored. This is called during the run phase of the test.

title: Reframe prints "Unknown error." whenever the test fails in a phase other than sanity and performance
body:
You can see this error even when running the `deps_complex.py` test:
```
$ ./bin/reframe -c unittests/resources/checks_unlisted/deps_complex.py -r 

[ReFrame Setup]
  version:           3.2-dev1 (rev: f42347ef)
  command:           './bin/reframe -c unittests/resources/checks_unlisted/deps_complex.py -r'
...
  * Job type: local (id=31724)
  * Maintainers: []
  * Failing phase: sanity
  * Rerun with '-n T2 -p builtin --system generic:default'
  * Reason: sanity error: 31 != 30
Sanity check failure
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
FAILURE INFO for T7 
  * Test Description: T7
  * System partition: generic
  * Environment: None
  * Stage directory: None
  * Node list: None
  * Job type: batch job (id=None)
  * Maintainers: []
  * Failing phase: startup
  * Rerun with '-n T7 -p None --system generic'
  * Reason: task dependency error: dependencies failed
Unknown error.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
....
```
The fix is very simple, it is caused by [this](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/master/reframe/frontend/statistics.py#L199) line. I think the final message (`Sanity check failure`) is not useful, and I would suggest we omit it completely. We already have the `* Failing phase: <phase>` line in the report.

title: Boostrapping throws an ensurepip error in Ubuntu
body:
In order to reproduce the problem, the following Dockerfile can be use:

```
FROM ubuntu

RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y python3 python3-pip python3-setuptools --no-install-recommends

RUN apt-get install -y git --no-install-recommends

RUN git clone https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe.git && \
    cd reframe && ./bootstrap.sh
```

Trying to build the above with Docker, it will throw the error in Step 4:
```
==> python3 -m ensurepip --root external/ --default-pip
/usr/bin/python3: No module named ensurepip
==> python3 -m pip install -q --upgrade pip --target=external/
==> python3 -m pip install -q -r requirements.txt --target=external/ --upgrade
```

Nevertheless, the bootstrapping continues fine.

title: dependence on git
body:
When I install reframe through `pip` in minimal docker container, it seems it can only work when git is installed; probably it just tries to use git to get the current commit for the version number (?). Is git a hard dependency? If I could do without it would reduce the size of my docker image by 80MB.

It seems a `depends_on('git', type='run')` dep in the spack package is missing too: https://github.com/spack/spack/blob/develop/var/spack/repos/builtin/packages/reframe/package.py.

title: Object of type '_DeferredExpression' is not JSON serializable
body:
This code will fail with:

```
version:           3.2-dev0 (rev: 576eb3f1)
PERFORMANCE REPORT
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
FailTest
- dom:login
   - PrgEnv-gnu
      * num_tasks: 1
      * elapsed_time: 8 s
      * filename: 8 (9.cpp)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
reframe: type error: ../../../../../../../../usr/lib64/python3.6/json/encoder.py:180: 
Object of type '_DeferredExpression' is not JSON serializable
                        o.__class__.__name__)
```

when run like this:

```bash
reframe -C cscs.py -p PrgEnv-gnu \
--keep-stage-files --prefix=$SCRATCH \
--report-file eff.json \
--performance-report -v -r -c bug_report.py'
``` 

I believe the issue is in the json reporting.

```python
import os, sys
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.simple_test
class FailTest(rfm.RunOnlyRegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.descr = ('RunOnlyRegressionTest')
        self.valid_systems = ['dom:login']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['PrgEnv-gnu']
        self.executable = 'echo 9.cpp'
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found('9', self.stdout)
        self.perf_patterns = {
            'elapsed_time': self.elapsed,
            'filename': self.elapsed,
        }
        self.reference = {
            '*': {
                'elapsed_time': (0, None, None, 's'),
                'filename': (0, None, None, self.fnm),
            }
        }

    @property
    @sn.sanity_function
    def elapsed(self):
        return 8

    @property
    @sn.sanity_function
    def fnm(self):
        return '(9.cpp)'
```

title: Default environment is required
body:
At the moment, reframe seems to require a default environment. If I do something like this:

```
        {
            'name':'openfoam',
            'target_systems': ['mysys:ib-gcc7-openmpi4-ucx'],
            'modules': ['openfoam-org/7-2ceqb4l']
        },
        {
            'name':'openfoam',
            'target_systems': ['mysys:ib-gcc9-openmpi4-ucx'],
            'modules': ['openfoam-org/7-4zgjbg2']
        },
```

Then I get a message like "environment 'openfoam' not defined for system 'mysys'" (paraphrased, lost the original terminal).

I have to add an empty default environment of the same name for it to work:
```
        {
            'name':'openfoam'
        },
```

Which is fine, because I can use the 'environs' values in the partition to restrict tests to valid partition+environ combinations. *Except* that it is an error trap - for example if I misspelt the 'target_systems' above, then reframe thinks there is a valid combination because of the default one, then I get a cryptic error during module loads.

To me that case with no default seems quite reasonable/normal, but maybe it's not.

title: Obliged to set references in RegressionTest?
body:
Hi -- firstly, I'd like to say thanks for developing ReFrame, a really nice tool!

Today I wanted to update from a 3.1-dev2 commit (c027bc70) to the 3.1 release, but this appears to introduce a non-backwards-compatible change (also the current master gives me this issue).

A somewhat minimal example looks like this, with [this file](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/v3.0-dev6/tutorial/src/example_matrix_vector_multiplication.c) as 'sources/example_matrix_vector_multiplication.c':
```python
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.simple_test
class Example1Test(rfm.RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.descr = 'Simple matrix-vector multiplication example'
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.time_limit = '00d00h01m00s'
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.sourcesdir = 'sources'
        self.sourcepath = 'example_matrix_vector_multiplication.c'
        self.build_system = 'SingleSource'
        self.build_system.cflags = ['-O2']
        self.executable_opts = ['1024', '100']
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found(
            r'time for single matrix vector multiplication', self.stdout)
        self.strict_check = False
        self.perf_patterns = {
            'time': sn.extractsingle(
                r'^time\sfor\ssingle\smatrix\svector\smultiplication\s(?P<perf>\S+)\ss$',
                self.stdout, 'perf', float),
        }

```
The setup/build/run/sanity steps seem to run fine, but the performance step crashes with
```
<path_to_reframe>/bin/reframe: unexpected error: not enough values to unpack (expected 5, got 4)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<path_to_reframe>/reframe/frontend/cli.py", line 772, in main
    run_stats = runner.stats.json()
  File "<path_to_reframe>/reframe/frontend/statistics.py", line 143, in json
    val, ref, lower, upper, unit = ref
ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 5, got 4)
```
In 3.1 (or the current master), this can be solved by setting a 'reference' attribute like this:
```
        self.reference = {
            '<system>:<partition>': {
                'time': (0.0004, -0.1, 0.1, 's'),
            }
        }
```
but this was not needed in the prior version I was using. The different behavior is probably related to this commit: https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/commit/9705d69355f7e3e9071a5dfd38d06b62868d2dfb. Is this a bug, or are we now "forced" to set references, even if only interested in performance logging and not in performance checking by ReFrame?

title: $id parameter in JSON schemas is wrong
body: It should be updated to refer to the correct location.

title: [test] Enhance workaround for PGI in CDT 20.06
Changes in `self.job.options` are inheritted in subsequent tests
body: Changes made in `self.job.options` made in one test case, propagate in subsequent tests. For example once the change in made here https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/a83cb2142cbd7d40a78336e055f1b78f6a922eea/cscs-checks/system/slurm/slurm.py#L182 then the following tests will run using altered `job.options`. This seems to be the case since a change made to that test changes the `sched_options` field of the executor policy which was used during the task setup https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/a83cb2142cbd7d40a78336e055f1b78f6a922eea/reframe/frontend/executors/policies.py#L64

title: Random failure of the `test_kbd_interrupt_in_wait_with_limited_concurrency` unit test
body:
The following failures happens randomly from time to time. I don't know if it actually corresponds to a bug in the code or is it a problem of this particular unit test.

```
_____________ test_kbd_interrupt_in_wait_with_limited_concurrency ______________
async_runner = (reframe.frontend.executors.Runner(_max_retries=0, _policy=reframe.frontend.executors.policies.AsynchronousExecutionPo...cs.TestStats(...)@0x7fdbd38f2908)@0x7fdbd38f2c18, <unittests.test_policies._TaskEventMonitor object at 0x7fdbd38f2208>)
make_cases = <function make_cases.<locals>._make_cases at 0x7fdbd34edc80>
make_async_exec_ctx = <function make_async_exec_ctx.<locals>._make_async_exec_ctx at 0x7fdbd34f46a8>
    def test_kbd_interrupt_in_wait_with_limited_concurrency(
            async_runner, make_cases, make_async_exec_ctx):
        # The general idea for this test is to allow enough time for all the
        # four checks to be submitted and at the same time we need the
        # KeyboardInterruptCheck to finish first (the corresponding wait should
        # trigger the failure), so as to make the framework kill the remaining
        # three.
        ctx = make_async_exec_ctx(2)
        next(ctx)
    
        runner, _ = async_runner
        with pytest.raises(KeyboardInterrupt):
            runner.runall(make_cases([
                KeyboardInterruptCheck(), SleepCheck(10),
>               SleepCheck(10), SleepCheck(10)
            ]))
E           Failed: DID NOT RAISE <class 'KeyboardInterrupt'>
unittests/test_policies.py:525: Failed
=========================== short test summary info ============================
FAILED unittests/test_policies.py::test_kbd_interrupt_in_wait_with_limited_concurrency
================== 1 failed, 619 passed, 88 skipped in 38.85s ==================
```

title: monkeypatching in e.g. run_before() methods
body:
I've got a test method decorated with a @run_before() method, like (for example):

```
@rfm.run_before('run')
def no_run(self):
        """ Turn the run phase into a no-op to help debugging. """

        with open(os.path.join(self.stagedir, 'noop.sh'), 'w') as noop:
            noop.write('#!/bin/bash\necho "noop $@"\n')
        self.executable = "./noop.sh"
```

which really I want to pull out into a separate library so I can use it on various classes (it's more complex than the method here so it makes more sense!).

I can't figure out how to monkey-patch this in though - the run_before decorator seems to make a difference. Ideally I'd do something like:

```
@set_no_run
@rfm.simple_test
class MyTest(rfm.RegressionTest):
    <snip>
```

I tried this:

```
def set_no_run(cls):

    def no_run(self):
        """ Turn the run phase into a no-op. """

        with open(os.path.join(self.stagedir, 'noop.sh'), 'w') as noop:
            noop.write('#!/bin/bash\necho "noop $@"\n')
        self.executable = "./noop.sh"

    cls.no_run = no_run
    cls.no_run = rfm.run_before('run')(cls.no_run)
    return cls
```

but (unsurprisingly?) that doesn't work (as in, doesn't change the executable).

Maybe I'm missing something about the way binding works in Py3 here but I'd appreciate any suggestions for how to do something like this, even if it's via another route.

title: Passing a `--constraint` job option should be combined with the  `access` one for Slurm
body:
If a `--contraint=A` option is used in the `access` field of the `SystemPartition` then a corresponding line is emitted inside the sbatch script.
Passing additionally a constraint in the `options` field of the `Job` class, such as  `--contstraint=B` emits a single line in the sbatch script after the line corresponding to `--constraint=A`.
Therefore, slurm takes into account only the `B` constraint.
The two constraint options should be combined and passed in a single line as: `--constraint=A,B`

title: Incorrect configuration value returned when a name-addressable object does not exist
body:
The following query returns the  wrong value:

```
./bin/reframe --show-config=environments/@foo/cxx -l
```

It returns `""`, which is the value set for the `builtin` environment, instead of `"CC"` which is the default value. Addressing objects by index works fine:

```
$ ./bin/reframe --show-config=environments/100/cxx -l
"CC"
```

title: Tasks waiting to run are silently aborted if a later task fails compile stage, with async policy
body:
This might be related to #1121 and/or #507 

When using the AsynchronousExecutionPolicy, a task failure at the compile if a tasks fails at the compile_wait step can lead to reframe exiting while earlier queued jobs are still waiting to run.

I think the root cause is in `reframe/frontend/executors/policies.py` -> `class AsynchronousExecutionPolicy(ExecutionPolicy, TaskEventListener)` ->   `def _reschedule(self, task):`, `compile_wait` can throw a variety of compile-time errors that should fail the task, but not abort the reframe run.

I have a patch that I think fixes this, will post an PR shortly

title: RuntimeContext missing documented attributes
body:
Some useful info is documented here:
https://reframe-hpc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference.html#reframe.core.runtime.RuntimeContext

However after doing
```
from reframe.core.runtime import runtime
```

then either `runtime().output_prefix` or `runtime().stage_prefix` fails with AttributeError.

Looks like actually there's an undocumented `HostResources` object as `runtime().resources` which provides these attributes. Have I understood the docs or are they wrong?

version 3.0-dev6 (rev: b7d5b016)

title: Recursive search mode for tests should not be the default
body: We made this default with the introduction of the new configuration, but I think it is wrong, because it practically renders useless the `-R` option by default. I suggest making default the non-recursive mode and set it to  `true` in our configuration  files.

title: State in documentation that `gcc` is needed to run the unit tests
Configuration conversion tool treats perflogdir wrongly
body:
`perflogdir` is no longer part of the system configuration. It is converted to the `basedir` attribute of the `filelog_handler`. This requires a not so straightforward change in the conversion tool, since if different systems define `perflogdir` differently, multiple entries in `logging` should be defined.

See #1242 for more details.

title: Module conflicts are ignored in module mappings
body:
In the following example `PrgEnv-gnu` loads `gcc/9.2.0`. Using the following mapping `-M 'PrgEnv-gnu: PrgEnv-gnu gcc/8.3.0'` it will cause the error when loading `gcc/8.3.0`:

```
gcc/8.3.0(3):ERROR:150: Module 'gcc/8.3.0' conflicts with the currently loaded module(s) 'gcc/9.2.0'
gcc/8.3.0(3):ERROR:102: Tcl command execution failed: conflict gcc
```

The problem is that the mapping module mechanism is not taking into account module conflicts in mappings. In this case the rhs of the mapping will `PrgEnv-gnu` with `gcc/9.2.0` and then it will try to load `gcc/8.3.0`, which will cause the error.

I don't know if this is easily fixable, but I am creating this issue to be listed as known issue at least. If we decide not to fix it, we should document it.

title: ReFrame crashes if verbosity level is increased
body:
This is the issue causing #1261. Just try the following:

```
./bin/reframe -c unittests/resources/checks/hellocheck.py -r -vv
```

The problem seems to come from [here](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/master/reframe/core/logging.py#L180), where we're overwriting the record's `check_job_completion_time`. It seems that the formatting function is called twice and the second time it will have a value (`str`) that cannot be passed to the converted in the line above.

title: logging inside regression test
body:
I'm running into some trouble with using the logging interface in my tests. Specifically, using `self.logging.log()` or any of the wrapper functions for it within a regression test fails when I have more than one logging target defined in the reframe configuration.

I define a logging configuration:

```
    logging_config = {
        'level': 'DEBUG',
        'handlers': [
            {
                'type': 'file',
                'name': 'reframe.log',
                'level': 'DEBUG',
                'format': '[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s: '
                          '%(check_info)s: %(message)s',
                'append': False,
            },

            # Output handling
            {
                'type': 'stream',
                'name': 'stdout',
                'level': 'DEBUG',
                'format': '%(message)s',
            },
            {
                'type': 'file',
                'name': 'reframe.out',
                'level': 'DEBUG',
                'format': '%(message)s',
                'append': False,
            }
        ]
    }
```
And I call the logger from within the regression test via:

```
	@rfm.run_after('run')
	def _meta_add_logs(self):
		log_level_names = rfm.core.logging._log_level_names

		# These only print correctly to first log in configuration file
		for level in log_level_names:
			self.logger.log(level, "logging {0}".format(level))
```

I would like to be able to dynamically add selected test results to the logging targets for a reframe run, but when I have more than one target (like reframe.log, reframe.out, stdout) only the first of the logging targets is generated correctly. The other logging targets generate an error message:

```
--- Logging error ---
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/msistaff/dunn0404/.conda/envs/reframe_deps/lib/python3.8/logging/__init__.py", line 1081, in emit
    msg = self.format(record)
  File "/home/msistaff/dunn0404/.conda/envs/reframe_deps/lib/python3.8/logging/__init__.py", line 925, in format
    return fmt.format(record)
  File "/panfs/roc/groups/14/msistaff/dunn0404/install_tests/ReFrame/reframe-3.0-dev3/reframe/core/logging.py", line 161, in format
    ct = self.converter(record.check_job_completion_time)
TypeError: an integer is required (got type str)
```

The issue seems to be related to the format of the date. On the first pass through the format function, the date is in the expected epoch format and can be converted. In subsequent passes, the date has already been formatted into the human-readable format specified in the config file, and the format function fails with the above message.

I am including a minimum failing example that can be run to generate the described behavior.


[logging_issue.tar.gz](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/files/4462499/logging_issue.tar.gz)

title: Torque job failed if standard output and error files are hosted until the job is completed
body:
This line is not sufficient to determine the job completeness if standard output and error files are hosted until the job is completed 

https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/007bc0b2b477a0ef86eeb4bb3b7eb00e4c0301ec/reframe/core/schedulers/torque.py#L95

We still need these line before return:
```
        with os_ext.change_dir(job.workdir):
            done = os.path.exists(job.stdout) and os.path.exists(job.stderr)
```

title: ReFrame crashes when trying to create a regression test interactively
body:
```
>>> import reframe as rfm
>>>
>>> @rfm.simple_test
... class MyTest(rfm.RegressionTest):
...     def __init__(self):
...             pass
...
>>> t = MyTest()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/karakasv/Repositories/reframe/reframe/core/pipeline.py", line 665, in __new__
    os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(inspect.getfile(cls))))
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/inspect.py", line 653, in getfile
    raise TypeError('{!r} is a built-in class'.format(object))
TypeError: <module '__main__' (built-in)> is a built-in class
```

The problem is that `inspect.getfile()` raises a `TypeError` if invoked from an interactive shell.

title: Setup hooks don't work for CompileOnlyRegressionTest
body:
The setup hooks are not called at all before/after the `setup` phase when a test is `CompileOnlyRegressionTest`. The reason is that the `setup()` function is overwritten in the `CompileOnlyRegressionTest` and the decorator is not inherited. 

Similarly in the `RunOnlyRegressionTest` the hooks for the `run` phase are called but not where we expect it. It is called before/after the call to the base class of `run` inside `RunOnlyRegressionTest.run()`.

Here is a simple example. When the test is `RegressionTest`.
```
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn

@rfm.simple_test
class Example1Test(rfm.RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.descr = 'Simple matrix-vector multiplication example'
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.sourcepath = 'example_matrix_vector_multiplication.c'
        self.executable_opts = ['1024', '100']
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found(
            r'time for single matrix vector multiplication', self.stdout)
        self.maintainers = ['you-can-type-your-email-here']
        self.tags = {'tutorial'}

    @rfm.run_before('setup')
    def test_hook(self):
        assert(0 == 1)
```

Output is failing (as it should) because of the hook:

title: ReFrame does not cancel the spawned test jobs if it receives a TERM signal
body: When Jenkins kills a job it sends the TERM signal. This will obviously cause ReFrame to terminate, but it will leave stale test jobs behind. We should treat it the same way we treat keyboard interrupts.

title: Duplicated check path leads to error
body:
Hi,
I had aliased the search path with 
`alias reframe='reframe -C /cvmfs/soft.computecanada.ca/custom/reframe/config/settings.py -c /cvmfs/soft.computecanada.ca/custom/reframe/checks'` 

Then, I wanted to use just a subdirectory, so I used : 
`reframe -R -r -c /cvmfs/soft.computecanada.ca/custom/reframe/checks/advanced/osu` 

but it failed because it found a duplicate test (i.e. the same one) :

title: Slurm sacct-based backend will block indefinitely if a submitted job lives across midnight
body: In order to avoid stale entries in the Slurm DB database, we pass the `-S <today>` option to `sacct`. "Today" is determined at submission time, so if a job finishes the next day, it will be lost and ReFrame will block indefinitely. I knew this bug existed, but this time I came across it, so I open the issue.

Scheduler-specific unit tests broken on master

title: ReqNodeNotAvail reason code causes ReFrame to incorrectly kill jobs on Cori at NERSC
body:
The Slurm scheduler on the Cori system at NERSC takes a long time to compute backfill - up to 15 minutes per backfill cycle, due to having a huge number of enqueued jobs (several 10,000s). During this process, Slurm will often temporarily change the reason code for an enqueued job to `ReqNodeNotAvail, UnavailableNodes:nid[...]`, where the list of nodes is essentially the entire system, around 11,000 nodes. Although ReFrame attempts to check if the nodes are healthy (cf. #303 and resulting PR), this check seems to fail on Cori while the backfill cycle is running. I don't understand why it fails, but wonder if Slurm refuses to service the `scontrol show node` command with such a large list of nodes.

I have worked around this problem by simply removing `ReqNodeNotAvail` from the `_cancel_reasons` list in `reframe/core/schedulers/slurm.py` in NERSC's fork of ReFrame, but this is probably not the best long-term solution. If it is true that Slurm is refusing to service the large `scontrol` command, can you think of a way to work around this problem?

title: Misleading error message for flexible tests with `num_tasks_per_node` > 1
body:
Assuming the following test:

```python
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.simple_test
class HostnameCheck(rfm.RunOnlyRegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.valid_systems = ['daint:gpu', 'daint:mc', 'dom:gpu', 'dom:mc']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['PrgEnv-cray']
        self.executable = 'hostname'
        self.sourcesdir = None
        self.num_tasks = 0
        self.num_tasks_per_node = 2
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_eq(
            self.num_tasks_assigned,
            sn.count(sn.findall(r'nid\d+', self.stdout))
        )

    @property
    @sn.sanity_function
    def num_tasks_assigned(self):
        return self.job.num_tasks
```

And running as follows:

```
./bin/reframe -C config/cscs.py -c ../misc/reframe-tests/flexible/hostname_check.py --flex-alloc-tasks=1 -r
```

gives the following error:

```
FAILURE INFO for HostnameCheck
  * System partition: dom:gpu
  * Environment: PrgEnv-cray
  * Stage directory: /users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/stage/dom/gpu/PrgEnv-cray/HostnameCheck
  * Job type: batch job (id=None)
  * Maintainers: []
  * Failing phase: run
  * Reason: job error: [jobid=None] could not find enough nodes: required 1, found 0
```

The purpose of the message is correct, because you want to abort execution if there are not enough *nodes*. However, `--flex-alloc-tasks`'s argument refers to *tasks* and everything internally is based on tasks. So, essentially, reframe assumes (correctly) that this test requires minimum two tasks to run (although they can be on the same node), and it compares that to the number provided from the user and fails. See [here](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/master/reframe/core/schedulers/__init__.py#L195). Then it prints this message which does not correspond to what it is actually doing. It would be typically correct if the message was referring to tasks. But then purpose of this whole feature would be lost, because you would have to know how many tasks per node each test requires, so as to pass it to the `--flex-alloc-tasks`. The correct behaviour would be to allow this test to run (with as many tasks per node that it likes) and interpret the argument to `--flex-alloc-tasks` as number of nodes (and perhaps rename the option).

title: Ignore inexistent nodes when discovering nodes in the flexible allocation scheme
body: Currently, if `scontrol show node unknown_node` returns an error, flex allocation fails. We should simply ignore unknown nodes and proceed with the rest.

title: [test] Fix openacc_cuda_mpi_cppstd.F90
body:
After merging the pull request #889, we are getting the following error:
```
 MPI test on GPU with OpenACC using  8 tasks
 Result : FAIL
 Expected value sum(f3):  55. actual value: 110.
``` 
I think that there is a mistake in the fix submitted by @cosunae: the array that should be checked for the `EXPECTED_CPP_STD_SUM` is `f2` and not `f3`, since only the first one is called as argument in `call_cpp_std`. What do you think @lxavier?

P.S.: I have replaced `cudaThreadSynchronize()` with `cudaDeviceSynchronize()` in `compute_cuda.cu` since the first one is deprecated.

title: ReFrame crashes if a test without a description is executed
body:
Example test:

```python
import os

import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.parameterized_test(['serial'], ['cuda'], ['openacc'])
class MiniAppTest(rfm.RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self, variant):
        self.valid_systems = ['daint:gpu']
        self.sourcesdir = os.path.join('../solutions', variant)
        if variant == 'cuda':
            self.valid_prog_environs = ['PrgEnv-gnu']
        elif variant == 'openacc':
            self.valid_prog_environs = ['PrgEnv-pgi']
        elif variant == 'serial':
            self.valid_prog_environs = ['PrgEnv-gnu', 'PrgEnv-pgi']

        self.executable = './main'
        self.executable_opts = ['256', '256', '100', '0.01']
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found(r'.+')
        self.perf_patterns = {
            'exec_time': sn.extractsingle(r'simulation took (\S+) seconds',
                                          self.stdout, 1, float),
            'perf': sn.extractsingle(r'at a rate of (\S+) iters/second',
                                     self.stdout, 1, float)
        }
        self.reference = {
            'daint:gpu': {
                'exec_time': (0, None, None, 's'),
                'perf': (0, None, None, 'iters/s')
            },
            '*': {
                'exec_time': (0, None, None, 's'),
                'perf': (0, None, None, 'iters/s')
            }
        }
```

title: `sourcepath` is ignored if build system is explicitly set
body:
This happens for all the build systems except `SingleSource` and is against what it it stated in the documentation [here](https://reframe-hpc.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference.html#reframe.core.pipeline.RegressionTest.sourcepath). Auto-detection works fine. My test structure is the following:

```python
ci/
    mytest.py
code/
    example1/
        makefile
    common/
```

The following test, which relies on auto-detection of the build system works fine:

```python
@rfm.simple_test
class MyTest(rfm.RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.sourcesdir = os.path.join(self.prefix, '../code')
        self.sourcepath = 'example1'
```

However, this one fails to set the `srcdir` of the build system as advertised in the documentation:

```python
@rfm.simple_test
class MyTest(rfm.RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        self.sourcesdir = os.path.join(self.prefix, '../code')
        self.sourcepath = 'example1'
        self.build_system = 'Make'
        # self.build_system.srcdir = 'example1' # workaround
```

The problem is that the following line should be one tab to the left...

https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/master/reframe/core/pipeline.py#L1003

title: ReFrame fails to load modules before job submission
body:
Issue reported by @bcfriesen in the Slack channel: 

> I have a question about how ReFarme handles Tcl modules. A few tests I am writing for NERSC require certain modules to be loaded before the job is submitted (the Slurm submit filter checks that the modules are loaded and rejects the job submission if they are not). However, when I add the necessary modules to the `setup()` phase, the logs indicate that ReFrame is indeed attempting to load them via `modulecmd python module load <module>`, but that seems to fail because when it submits the job to Slurm, the job is rejected because the module is not loaded. Any ideas what is going on?
I notice that `modulecmd python load <module>` takes no action other than printing the environment changes that it _would_ make to the terminal. I wonder if ReFrame is not actually evaluating these outputs for some reason?

This looks like a regression in ReFrame. Some time ago (when we introduced the build systems) we changed slightly the behaviour of the `setup()`, and its only purpose now is to record the necessary load/unload sequence of modules. In the past, we kept the environment (in Python) until the end of the test, that’s why this scenario worked then but not now. I will open an issue about that. For the moment, you can run ReFrame with `-m MODULE`, which will load `MODULE` before starting running any test.

title: ReFrame fails with Tcl versions that use modulecmd.tcl as executable
body:
ReFrame checks for the module system by running the `modulecmd` command.

Some versions of Tcl do not have the `modulecmd` binary. Instead they use the script `~/libexec/modulecmd.tcl` which is used by the `module` function in a similar way to `modulecmd`. They can not be replaced between each other, doing a symlink from `modulecmd.tcl` to `modulecmd` doesn't work as ReFrame gives `configuration error: could not find a sane Tmod installation`.

The details of the `module` function can be found with `type -a _moduleraw`. In the cases where the `modulecmd.tcl` is used, `module` depends on another function: `_moduleraw`. With `type -a _moduleraw` it can be seen that it used `libexec/modulecmd.tcl`.

title: Flexible task allocation is broken on master
body:
It has broken by the changes introduced in #724. More specifically, `SystemPartition` became immutable and returns read-only views of its internals. `guess_num_tasks()` tries to add some options and the `+` operator is not supported by the view:

Example backtrace:

```
FAILURE INFO for GpuBurnTest
  * System partition: dom:gpu
  * Environment: PrgEnv-gnu
  * Stage directory: /users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/stage/dom/gpu/PrgEnv-gnu/GpuBurnTest
  * Job type: batch job (id=None)
  * Maintainers: ['AJ', 'VK', 'TM']
  * Failing phase: run
  * Reason: unexpected error: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'SequenceView' and 'list'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/frontend/executors/__init__.py", line 125, in _safe_call
    return fn(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/pipeline.py", line 1044, in run
    self._job.prepare(commands, environs, login=True)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/schedulers/slurm.py", line 100, in prepare
    super().prepare(commands, environs, **gen_opts)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/schedulers/__init__.py", line 231, in prepare
    guessed_num_tasks = self.guess_num_tasks()
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/schedulers/__init__.py", line 274, in guess_num_tasks
    self.sched_access + self.options)
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'SequenceView' and 'list'

```

title: 'stable' version in documentation still points to 2.16
body: Despite the release of 2.17

title: Unit test fails on NFS
body:
* Unittests in `test_policies.py` fail during `tearDown` where `rmtree` is called. 
* The error message is of the following type:
`OSError: [Errno 16] Device or resource busy: '.nfs0000000002d707290000`

title: Improper handling of showing nodes by name via scontrol
body:
When executing `scontrol show -a -o node <nodenames>` the output may contain lines such as: `Node foo not found`  while other lines contain the proper node information. In this case, although the `scontrol` return status is **!=0**, the output should be parsed ignoring the nodes that are not found.

This has happened a few times when the CI is running the unittests. Take a look [here](https://jenkins.cscs.ch/view/Reframe%20Regression/job/ReframeCI/1565/).

title: Default partition in flexible tests overrides the partition passed in `access`
Versions v2.13-v2.16 not found in documentation
body: When selecting another version from the latest documentation page, versions v2.13-v2.16 throw a `Page not found` error.

title: PR #635 has broken Kesch environments
body: The error is visible also in the failure of #681 [here](https://jenkins.cscs.ch/blue/organizations/jenkins/ReframeCI/detail/ReframeCI/1528/pipeline). It appears that loading the environment during `setup()` crashes if an environment variable contains inline commands.

title: Performance failure report prints 'sanity error' which is confusing
body: This is known "bug" and is due to the fact that mechanism of sanity and performance patterns is the same; the same sanity functions are used in both. The sanity functions always raise a `SanityError` in case of errors, which is reported as "sanity error". We can fix that by reraising sanity errors as a `PerformanceError`, which will be reported differently.

title: 'keep_files' parameter can not save directories
body:
`keep_files` cannot save directories as described in the reference
```
List of files to be kept after the test finishes.

By default, the framework saves the standard output, the standard error and the generated shell script that was used to run this test.

These files will be copied over to the framework’s output directory during the cleanup() phase.

Directories are also accepted in this field.

Relative path names are resolved against the stage directory.
```
In `core/pipeline.py`,  the function `_copy_to_outputdir` calls `shutil.copy`  which can not copy directories.

title: Flexible node allocations ignore the default partition
body: This is the reason why `-P normal` is required to run on Dom, for example.

title: Sanity functions with closures might result in unexpected behaviour
body:
Here is an example:

```python
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.simple_test
class SSHLoginEnvCheck(rfm.RunOnlyRegressionTest):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.descr = ('Check if a set of environment variables is '
                      'defined when accessing remotely over SSH')
        self.valid_systems = ['daint:login', 'dom:login']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['PrgEnv-cray']
        reference = {
            'CRAY_CPU_TARGET': 'haswell',
            'CRAYPE_NETWORK_TARGET': 'aries',
            'MODULEPATH': r'[\S+]',
            'MODULESHOME': r'/opt/cray/pe/modules/[\d+\.+]',
            'PE_PRODUCT_LIST': 'CRAYPE_HASWELL:CRAY_RCA:CRAY_ALPS:DVS:'
                               'CRAY_XPMEM:CRAY_DMAPP:CRAY_PMI:CRAY_UGNI:'
                               'CRAY_UDREG:CRAY_LIBSCI:CRAYPE:CRAY:'
                               'PERFTOOLS:CRAYPAT',
            'SCRATCH': r'/scratch/[\S+]',
            'XDG_RUNTIME_DIR': r'/run/user/[\d+]'
        }
        self.executable = 'ssh'
        echo_args = ' '.join('%s=$%s' % (i, i)  for i in reference.keys())
        self.executable_opts = [self.current_system.name,
                                'echo', "'%s'" % echo_args]
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.all(
            sn.map(lambda x: sn.assert_found(x, self.stdout), ['CRAY_CPU_TARGET=haswell']))
        self.maintainers = ['RS', 'LM']
        self.tags = {'maintenance'}
```

This produces the following error:

```
FAILURE INFO for SSHLoginEnvCheck
  * System partition: dom:login
  * Environment: PrgEnv-cray
  * Stage directory: /users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/stage/dom/login/PrgEnv-cray/SSHLoginEnvCheck
  * Job type: local (id=3983)
  * Maintainers: ['RS', 'LM']
  * Failing phase: sanity
  * Reason: unexpected error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'stdout'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/frontend/executors/__init__.py", line 58, in _safe_call
    return fn(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/pipeline.py", line 1060, in sanity
    self.check_sanity()
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/pipeline.py", line 1078, in check_sanity
    success = evaluate(self.sanity_patterns)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/deferrable.py", line 344, in evaluate
    return expr.evaluate()
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/deferrable.py", line 52, in evaluate
    ret = self._fn(*fn_args, **fn_kwargs)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/utility/sanity.py", line 117, in all
    return builtins.all(iterable)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/deferrable.py", line 63, in __bool__
    return builtins.bool(self.evaluate())
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/deferrable.py", line 45, in evaluate
    arg.evaluate() if isinstance(arg, type(self)) else arg)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/deferrable.py", line 52, in evaluate
    ret = self._fn(*fn_args, **fn_kwargs)
  File "/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/reframe/core/pipeline.py", line 689, in stdout
    return self._job.stdout
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'stdout'
```

The problem is that we deep copy the regression test object before running it for each programming environment and system partition, but the function closures are not deep copied. As a result, `self` in the above example refers to the original object, thus leading to this error.

This bug is another limitation of the deep copying of regression tests described in #55.

**Workaround**: Avoid sanity function with mutable closures. The above example could be rewritten as follows:

```python
    def __init__(self):
        ...
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.all(
            sn.map(self.assert_envvar, ['CRAY_CPU_TARGET=haswell']))

    def assert_envvar(self, v):
        return sn.assert_found(v, self.stdout)
```

title: Build jobs are killed after 10 minutes
body: It would be nice to have an option to set the time limit for the build job.

title: ReFrame silently ignores wrong test files
body:
The following wrong test file is simply ignored by ReFrame:

```python
import reframe as rfm
import reframe.utility.sanity as sn


@rfm.simple_test
class SedTest(rfm.CompileOnlyTest):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.sourcesdir = 'https://github.com/mirror/sed'
        self.prebuild_cmd = ['autoreconf -vfi']
        self.build_system = 'Autotools'
        self.build_system.builddir = 'build'
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found('.*', self.stdout)
```

```
Command line: ./bin/reframe -C config/tresa.py -c ../misc/rfm-checks/sed.py -l
Reframe version: 2.14-dev2
Launched by user: karakasv
Launched on host: tresa.local
Reframe paths
=============
    Check prefix      :
    Check search path : '../misc/rfm-checks/sed.py'
    Stage dir prefix     : /Users/karakasv/Repositories/reframe/stage/
    Output dir prefix    : /Users/karakasv/Repositories/reframe/output/
    Perf. logging prefix : /Users/karakasv/Repositories/reframe/perflogs
List of matched checks
======================
Found 0 check(s).
```

The problem in this file is that the base class for compile-only tests is `CompileOnlyRegressionTest` not `CompileOnlyTest`. I think it has something to do with the initial parsing of the source files.

title: The environment variables are exported twice in the job script
'logdir' system attribute in configuration file does not work correctly
body:
The behavior with the logdir handling seems to be strange. If I define the `logdir` option at the machine specification in reframe/settings.py, it sets that directory for `Stage dir` and `Output dir`, but not for `Perf. logging prefix`. Using the `perflogdir` option instead in the reframe/settings.py has no effect. 

Using the command line option `--perflogdir` seems to work fine.

title: Empty lines in built job scripts

milestone.title: Summer sprint
milestone.description: This is not a real sprint but a rather a pool of items, where we are going to draw items from for the next month.

body:
For example for the petsc example the job script contains the following:

```
#!/bin/bash -l
#SBATCH --job-name="rfm_PetscPoisson2DCheck_dynamic_job"
#SBATCH --time=0:10:0
#SBATCH --ntasks=16
#SBATCH --ntasks-per-node=8








#SBATCH --output=/users/manitart/reframe_dev_public/stage/dom/gpu/PrgEnv-cray/PetscPoisson2DCheck_dynamic/rfm_PetscPoisson2DCheck_dynamic_job.out
#SBATCH --error=/users/manitart/reframe_dev_public/stage/dom/gpu/PrgEnv-cray/PetscPoisson2DCheck_dynamic/rfm_PetscPoisson2DCheck_dynamic_job.err

#SBATCH --constraint=gpu
module load daint-gpu
module load PrgEnv-cray
module load cray-petsc
srun ./PetscPoisson2DCheck_dynamic -da_grid_x 4 -da_grid_y 4 -ksp_monitor
```

This seems to have been introduced by #340 since in the `finalize` method of `ShellScriptGenerator` when joining `\n` with a list that contain empty strings, empty lines are introduced.

title: --timestamp command-line option is ignored
body: This was broken when the new-style checks and the runtime refactoring PR (#264) has been merged.

title: 'ReqNodeNotAvail' is not always a reason of indefinite blocking of a job
body:
In fact, on Kesch this is the reason we get when a job is just pending:

```
ReqNodeNotAvail,  UnavailableNodes:
```

I think here the key is that the `UnavailableNodes` list is empty. Perhaps, we need to have a more robust check before cancelling the job.

title: Namd cpu check does not have the production tag
Filename information on syntax errors in user test files is missed
body:
Example traceback:

```
/apps/common/UES/jenkins/SLES12/easybuild/software/reframe/2.11/bin/reframe: unexpected error: invalid syntax (<unknown>, line 47)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/apps/common/UES/jenkins/SLES12/easybuild/software/reframe/2.11/reframe/frontend/cli.py", line 339, in main

    checks.extend(self.load_from_file(d, **check_args))
  File "/apps/common/UES/jenkins/SLES12/easybuild/software/reframe/2.11/reframe/frontend/loader.py", line 99, in load_from_file
    if not self._validate_source(filename):
  File "/apps/common/UES/jenkins/SLES12/easybuild/software/reframe/2.11/reframe/frontend/loader.py", line 64, in _validate_source
    source_tree = ast.parse(f.read())
  File "/apps/common/UES/jenkins/SLES12/easybuild/software/Python-bare/3.6.2/lib/python3.6/ast.py", line 35, in parse
    return compile(source, filename, mode, PyCF_ONLY_AST)
  File "<unknown>", line 47
    'MPICH_RDMA_ENABLED_CUDA': '1'
                             ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

The problems comes from how we do the AST parsing in `frontend/loader.py`:

```python
        with open(filename, 'r') as f:
            source_tree = ast.parse(f.read())

        validator = RegressionCheckValidator()
        validator.visit(source_tree)
        return validator.valid

```

title: Module mappings have no effect in the generated job script
body:
Example test file:

```python
import os

import reframe.utility.sanity as sn
from reframe.core.pipeline import RegressionTest


class HelloTest(RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
        super().__init__('hellocheck', os.path.dirname(__file__), **kwargs)
        self.descr = 'C Hello World test'

        # All available systems are supported
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.sourcepath = 'hello.c'
        self.tags = {'foo', 'bar'}
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found(r'Hello, World\!', self.stdout)
        self.maintainers = ['VK']
        self.modules = ['testmod_foo']


def _get_checks(**kwargs):
    return [HelloTest(**kwargs)]
```

Run as follows:
```
module use unittests/modules
./reframe.py -M testmod_foo:testmod_bar -C config/cscs.py -c unittests/resources/hellocheck.py -p PrgEnv-gnu --system=daint:login -r
```

Generated run script:

```bash
cat output/login/hellocheck/PrgEnv-gnu/hellocheck_daint_login_PrgEnv-gnu.sh
#!/bin/bash -l
module unload PrgEnv-cray
module load PrgEnv-gnu
module unload PrgEnv-cray
module load testmod_foo
./hellocheck
```

Excerpt from `reframe.log`:

```
[2018-04-18T17:19:21] debug: hellocheck on daint:login using PrgEnv-gnu: executing OS command: modulecm
d python show testmod_bar
[2018-04-18T17:19:21] debug: hellocheck on daint:login using PrgEnv-gnu: executing OS command: modulecm
d python load testmod_bar
```

title: Fix CDO/NCO compatibility checks that rely on empty stderr
body:
The stderr may contain information which do not constitute failure of the check:

* [nco_module_compat](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/0890e215b6a1abbe2413dc7319ebb376e38db4e7/cscs-checks/tools/io/cdo.py#L75)

* [cdo_module_compat](https://github.com/eth-cscs/reframe/blob/0890e215b6a1abbe2413dc7319ebb376e38db4e7/cscs-checks/tools/io/nco.py#L71)

title: Default settings are not loaded if ReFrame is invoked from a different directory
body:
```
~/Devel/reframe/bin/reframe -c ci-scripts/hellocheck.py -r
/users/karakasv/Devel/reframe/bin/reframe: could not load settings: could not load configuration file `reframe/settings.py': [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'reframe/settings.py'
```

The problem is that we are always looking for `reframe/setttings.py` in the current working directory, whereas we should look in the "installation" directory of ReFrame. The solution is to do the same thing we do for the default checks lookup.

title: Inconsistent description of the CUDA tutorial test
body: In example7, the description talks about a 'matrixmul test', whereas the sanity patterns look for the result of a  'single matrix vector multiplication'. All tutorial examples must be double checked for such inconsistencies and corrected if necessary (also in the documentation).

title: Infinite recursion during copying to stage directory if 'sourcesdir' is a relative path
body:
Here is the scenario, which is a typical scenario for usage of the framework as development CI tool:

#### Directory structure
```
ci-scripts/
    hellocheck.py
src/
    hello.c
```

#### hello.c

```C
#include <stdio.h>

int main()
{
    printf("Hello, World!\n");
    return 0;
}
```

#### hellocheck.py

```python
import os

import reframe.utility.sanity as sn
from reframe.core.pipeline import RegressionTest


class HelloTest(RegressionTest):
    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
        super().__init__('hellocheck', os.path.dirname(__file__), **kwargs)
        self.descr = 'C Hello World test'

        # All available systems are supported
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.sourcesdir = os.path.join(self.prefix, '..')
        self.sourcepath = 'hello.c'
        self.tags = {'foo', 'bar'}
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found(r'Hello, World\!', self.stdout)
        self.maintainers = ['VK']


def _get_checks(**kwargs):
    return [HelloTest(**kwargs)]
```

```
reframe -c ci-scripts/hellocheck.py -r
```

title: Function 'git_repo_exists' returns False even though the repository exits
body: The problem seems to happen for remote repositories that have many branches

title: The serial execution policy does not cancel the spawned job upon abort
Update documentation and 2.10 release notes for the changes in logging configuration
body: The `testcase_name` has changed to `check_info` and now the `check_info` message can be documented per test. This has caused a couple of problems already: #88 and #138.

title: Adapt CDO/NCO tests to the new Slurm behaviour
body: All the CDO/NCO tests that require empty output are now failing due to the statistics information that it is now printed out in the standard output by `srun`.

title: CI's retry command does not affect all pipeline stages
Slurm's --exclusive is always set in the job scripts
body: The problem comes from how we emit the job options in preamble. We emit them iff the corresponding `Job` attributes are not `None`. However, this option is always set to `False` (i.e., not `None`) and, thus, it is always emitted.

title: Formatting problems for sanity errors
body:
Sanity errors are reported simply as `ReframeError`. A test demonstrating this and the corresponding output follow:

```python
import os

import reframe.utility.sanity as sn
from reframe.core.pipeline import RunOnlyRegressionTest


class SanityErrorTest(RunOnlyRegressionTest):
    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
        super().__init__('sanity_error_check', os.path.dirname(__file__), **kwargs)
        self.valid_systems = ['*']
        self.valid_prog_environs = ['*']
        self.sourcesdir = None
        self.executable = 'hostname'
        self.sanity_patterns = sn.assert_found(r'foo', self.stdout)


def _get_checks(**kwargs):
    return [SanityErrorTest(**kwargs)]
```

```
Command line: ./reframe.py --system=generic -c mytests/nooutput.py -r

Launched on host: tresa.local
```

title: Jenkins CI not set up properly on Kesch
body: It seems that the Jenkins' slave on Kesch is a compute node and ReFrame does not recognise it. We should launch the CI and run ReFrame on the login nodes.

title: Revisit the way frontend options are passed to the scheduler backends
body:
Currently, this is controlled by the `sched_*` arguments plus the `sched_options`. The problem with this approach is bugs like [this](https://madra.cscs.ch/scs/reframe/issues/526). I think the best way to pass everything through `sched_options` or `options` and each back end should map specific properties to options. This is a rough idea, we should work on it a bit.

Internal issue: https://madra.cscs.ch/scs/reframe/issues/543

title: System and partition initialisation are random
body:
This is due to the fact that both systems and partitions are defined as dictionaries. This has several repercussions:

* No specific order that the regression goes through the partitions during the phase of test execution.
* Hostname matching rules must be unique. No last resort, catch-all pattern may be placed, since this may be tried earlier and lead to false system detection.

With Python 3.7 normal dictionaries will become ordered, but it's better not to rely on that.

Internal issue: https://madra.cscs.ch/scs/reframe/issues/234

title: The job script generators change too late to the working directory
body:
Quoting from @bcfriesen:

> Actually, now there is a new issue related to this.

> When using DataWarp, the scheduler creates a new temporary directory on the DataWarp file system which is pointed to by an environment variable. For "striped" access, the environment variable is $DW_JOB_STRIPED. The data specified by the #DW stage_in header in the batch script is automatically copied to $DW_JOB_STRIPED. The remainder of the batch script typically involves copying the executable into $DW_JOB_STRIPED, because the value of that environment variable changes with every run (so it can't be hard-coded into the batch script, or into the code itself).

> I tried to address this by writing a simple bash script which copies the executable into $DW_JOB_STRIPED:

> ```#!/bin/bash
> EXE=a.out
> cp $EXE $DW_JOB_STRIPED
> cd $DW_JOB_STRIPED
> ```
> and putting it into the self.job.pre_run stage as described here. The issue is that the auto-generated Slurm script will execute that bash script, but then follow it immediately with cd /path/to/stagedir, as specified by the stagedir in the _site_configuration. So the test never actually tests the functionality of DataWarp because it reads everything from stagedir, which is not on the DataWarp file system.

Yes, this is indeed a problem of our job script generator. The `cd` to the working directory should be done at the very beginning or we should try using the `--workdir` option of Slurm instead.
